\n\n
\n\n \n \n\n \n \n \n\n","date":"2023-02-06 22:02:53 -0600","tags":[],"url":"/lectures/Lec-MT3","next":{"excerpt":"

Course policies can be found on the website ecealgo.com.

\n","title":"Lecture 1 - Course introduction and languages","categories":[],"previous":{"title":"No Lecture","categories":[],"name":"Lec-MT3.md","date":"2023-02-06 22:02:53 -0600","tags":[],"url":"/lectures/Lec-MT3","collection":"lectures","path":"_lectures/Lec-MT3.md","relative_path":"_lectures/Lec-MT3.md","id":"/lectures/Lec-MT3","draft":false,"subtitle":"(Midterm 3)","placeholder":true,"card-link":"LecLinkMT3","back-color":"ffeeff","description":null,"people":["kani"],"layout":"lecture","no-link":true,"deliverydate":"2023-04-27","slug":"Lec-MT3","ext":".md"},"content":"

Course policies can be found on the website ecealgo.com.

\n\n

Big Questions

\n\n

This course is focused on answering three big questions:

\n\n
    \n
  • Given infinite time, how can we group problems by their complexity (Computability-theory)
    • \n
  • Given finite time, but a problem we know is computable, how fast can we solve the problem (Algorithmic design)
    • \n
  • Given a problem which is difficult to solve, can we infer how slow/fast we can solve it by comparing it to other known problems (Reductions)
    • \n
\n\n

\n

Two types of complexity

\n

\n\n\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n
Computational ComplexityAlgorithmic Complexity
\n\n

\n

Why Languages?

\n

Problems need to be represented as languages to be comparable. A language is a set of strings and each string represents and instance of the problem (a specific set of inputs and their correponding output). For example, the problem of adding two numbers together can be represented by the language:

\n\n

Problem: Multiplying two integers together

\n\n

Language: \n\\(L_{MULT2} = \n\\begin{bmatrix}\n 1 \\times 1|1, & 1 \\times 2|2, & 1 \\times 3|3, \\ldots\\\\\n 2 \\times 1|2, & 2 \\times 2|4, & 2 \\times 3|6, \\ldots \\\\\n \\vdots & \\vdots & \\vdots \\\\\n n \\times 1|n, & n \\times 2|2n, & n \\times 3|3n, \\ldots \\\\\n\\end{bmatrix}\\)

\n\n

\n

Things I forgot to mention

\n

You would think that after talking for 1.25 hours, what else could there be to say. Well my friends, there is so much to know and by extension, just as must to teach! This is what I forgot to mention today.

\n\n
Group homeworks
\n

Homeworks can be completed in groups of at most three students as discussed in the homework policies. Ideally, the way it should work is that each individual in a group looks at all the problems and comes up with some quick notes on possible solutions. Then the group would come together and attempt to reach a consensus on each problem. Finally, the solution writing and presentation would be divvyed up between the members so alleviate some of the presentation burden. However, I personally am conflicted on group work:

\n\n
    \n
  • Positive: If done correctly, it can be a powerful way where students learn from and bounce ideas off one-another. That is definitely a good thing.
    • \n
  • Negative: Since this is my sixth time doing this course, I believe about half the groups simply divvy up the problems and dont even look at the problems not assigned to them. Ive done a bit of analysis on past semesters where Ive had a exam problem that was nearly identical to a homework problem and consistently, theres been about 25-30% of students that clearly have never seen the problem before.
    • \n
\n\n

In summary, I tend to fall of the side of discouraging group work. From what Ive seen, the strongest performing individuals are over-represented in the group of students that do the homework solo. Also I have reduced the homework burden compared to past semesters so a single person should be fine doing all the problems themselves. \nBut, I wont get rid of group homeworks all together. Like I say a lot, you guys are adults and should know what works best for you. My job is to encourage behavior that I believe will be optimal for learning, not force it.

\n\n
Earlier HW Assignment
\n

One of you made an excellent point after class that if I want to encourage starting homework early, I should post the homework on Friday instead on Monday. The argument is that if I post it on Friday, people usually have free time on the weekend to start right away while if I post on Monday, there are more things going on during the week and a lot of you wont have time to get to it till the next weekend. What a excellent criticism (I mean that sincerely) and it something I hadnt considered. SO I wont promise anything, but the deal is I will do my absolute best to post the homework by Friday midnight. The homework will cover every learned the Tuesday-Friday right before it. The due date is still the next Monday (so itll be 10 days between the assignment and submission instead of 7). The one downside is that the next homework will get assigned before the current one is due which might be a little emotionally discouraging but the benefit of allowing people to start early right after completing the requisite lectures/labs outweighs that.

\n\n
DRES
\n
    \n
  • If you have a DRES accommodation, please email me directly (not sure if sending documents over Piazza is compliant with EHR policies or not, but why risk it ). Make sure I respond that Ive recorded your accommodation! If I dont respond email again.
    • \n
  • Because of the limited staff, DRES students will take the exams at the TAC synchronously with the rest of the class. Well hammer out the details closer to MT1.
    • \n
\n\n
Labs/Discussions are the same thing
\n

Labs and discussions are the same thing. Sorry, Ive used both terms interchangeably, Ive taught this course so many times with different people, my mind keeps jumping timelines with the exact verbiage.

\n\n

\n

Additional Resources

\n

    • \n

Lecture 1 - Course introduction and languages

\n \n\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n
Date Pre-lecture slides Post-lecture scribbles Lecture recording
\n January 17 2023\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n
\n \n  \n\n

Notes

\n\n
\n

Course policies can be found on the website ecealgo.com.

\n\n

Big Questions

\n\n

This course is focused on answering three big questions:

\n\n
    \n
  • Given infinite time, how can we group problems by their complexity (Computability-theory)
    • \n
  • Given finite time, but a problem we know is computable, how fast can we solve the problem (Algorithmic design)
    • \n
  • Given a problem which is difficult to solve, can we infer how slow/fast we can solve it by comparing it to other known problems (Reductions)
    • \n
\n\n

\n

Two types of complexity

\n

\n\n\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n
Computational ComplexityAlgorithmic Complexity
\n\n

\n

Why Languages?

\n

Problems need to be represented as languages to be comparable. A language is a set of strings and each string represents and instance of the problem (a specific set of inputs and their correponding output). For example, the problem of adding two numbers together can be represented by the language:

\n\n

Problem: Multiplying two integers together

\n\n

Language: \n\\(L_{MULT2} = \n\\begin{bmatrix}\n 1 \\times 1|1, & 1 \\times 2|2, & 1 \\times 3|3, \\ldots\\\\\n 2 \\times 1|2, & 2 \\times 2|4, & 2 \\times 3|6, \\ldots \\\\\n \\vdots & \\vdots & \\vdots \\\\\n n \\times 1|n, & n \\times 2|2n, & n \\times 3|3n, \\ldots \\\\\n\\end{bmatrix}\\)

\n\n

\n

Things I forgot to mention

\n

You would think that after talking for 1.25 hours, what else could there be to say. Well my friends, there is so much to know and by extension, just as must to teach! This is what I forgot to mention today.

\n\n
Group homeworks
\n

Homeworks can be completed in groups of at most three students as discussed in the homework policies. Ideally, the way it should work is that each individual in a group looks at all the problems and comes up with some quick notes on possible solutions. Then the group would come together and attempt to reach a consensus on each problem. Finally, the solution writing and presentation would be divvyed up between the members so alleviate some of the presentation burden. However, I personally am conflicted on group work:

\n\n
    \n
  • Positive: If done correctly, it can be a powerful way where students learn from and bounce ideas off one-another. That is definitely a good thing.
    • \n
  • Negative: Since this is my sixth time doing this course, I believe about half the groups simply divvy up the problems and dont even look at the problems not assigned to them. Ive done a bit of analysis on past semesters where Ive had a exam problem that was nearly identical to a homework problem and consistently, theres been about 25-30% of students that clearly have never seen the problem before.
    • \n
\n\n

In summary, I tend to fall of the side of discouraging group work. From what Ive seen, the strongest performing individuals are over-represented in the group of students that do the homework solo. Also I have reduced the homework burden compared to past semesters so a single person should be fine doing all the problems themselves. \nBut, I wont get rid of group homeworks all together. Like I say a lot, you guys are adults and should know what works best for you. My job is to encourage behavior that I believe will be optimal for learning, not force it.

\n\n
Earlier HW Assignment
\n

One of you made an excellent point after class that if I want to encourage starting homework early, I should post the homework on Friday instead on Monday. The argument is that if I post it on Friday, people usually have free time on the weekend to start right away while if I post on Monday, there are more things going on during the week and a lot of you wont have time to get to it till the next weekend. What a excellent criticism (I mean that sincerely) and it something I hadnt considered. SO I wont promise anything, but the deal is I will do my absolute best to post the homework by Friday midnight. The homework will cover every learned the Tuesday-Friday right before it. The due date is still the next Monday (so itll be 10 days between the assignment and submission instead of 7). The one downside is that the next homework will get assigned before the current one is due which might be a little emotionally discouraging but the benefit of allowing people to start early right after completing the requisite lectures/labs outweighs that.

\n\n
DRES
\n
    \n
  • If you have a DRES accommodation, please email me directly (not sure if sending documents over Piazza is compliant with EHR policies or not, but why risk it ). Make sure I respond that Ive recorded your accommodation! If I dont respond email again.
    • \n
  • Because of the limited staff, DRES students will take the exams at the TAC synchronously with the rest of the class. Well hammer out the details closer to MT1.
    • \n
\n\n
Labs/Discussions are the same thing
\n

Labs and discussions are the same thing. Sorry, Ive used both terms interchangeably, Ive taught this course so many times with different people, my mind keeps jumping timelines with the exact verbiage.

\n\n

\n

Additional Resources

\n
    \n
  • Jeffs Textbook - Introduction and History
    • \n
  • Jeffs - Notes on strings
    • \n
  • Sariels Lecture 1
    • \n
\n\n
\n\n

\n","title":"Lecture 10 - Recursion and reductions","categories":[],"previous":{"excerpt":"

Course policies can be found on the website ecealgo.com.

\n","title":"Lecture 1 - Course introduction and languages","categories":[],"previous":{"title":"No Lecture","categories":[],"name":"Lec-MT3.md","date":"2023-02-06 22:02:53 -0600","tags":[],"url":"/lectures/Lec-MT3","collection":"lectures","path":"_lectures/Lec-MT3.md","relative_path":"_lectures/Lec-MT3.md","id":"/lectures/Lec-MT3","draft":false,"subtitle":"(Midterm 3)","placeholder":true,"card-link":"LecLinkMT3","back-color":"ffeeff","description":null,"people":["kani"],"layout":"lecture","no-link":true,"deliverydate":"2023-04-27","slug":"Lec-MT3","ext":".md"},"content":"

Course policies can be found on the website ecealgo.com.

\n\n

Big Questions

\n\n

This course is focused on answering three big questions:

\n\n
    \n
  • Given infinite time, how can we group problems by their complexity (Computability-theory)
    • \n
  • Given finite time, but a problem we know is computable, how fast can we solve the problem (Algorithmic design)
    • \n
  • Given a problem which is difficult to solve, can we infer how slow/fast we can solve it by comparing it to other known problems (Reductions)
    • \n
\n\n

\n

Two types of complexity

\n

\n\n\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n
Computational ComplexityAlgorithmic Complexity
\n\n

\n

Why Languages?

\n

Problems need to be represented as languages to be comparable. A language is a set of strings and each string represents and instance of the problem (a specific set of inputs and their correponding output). For example, the problem of adding two numbers together can be represented by the language:

\n\n

Problem: Multiplying two integers together

\n\n

Language: \n\\(L_{MULT2} = \n\\begin{bmatrix}\n 1 \\times 1|1, & 1 \\times 2|2, & 1 \\times 3|3, \\ldots\\\\\n 2 \\times 1|2, & 2 \\times 2|4, & 2 \\times 3|6, \\ldots \\\\\n \\vdots & \\vdots & \\vdots \\\\\n n \\times 1|n, & n \\times 2|2n, & n \\times 3|3n, \\ldots \\\\\n\\end{bmatrix}\\)

\n\n

\n

Things I forgot to mention

\n

You would think that after talking for 1.25 hours, what else could there be to say. Well my friends, there is so much to know and by extension, just as must to teach! This is what I forgot to mention today.

\n\n
Group homeworks
\n

Homeworks can be completed in groups of at most three students as discussed in the homework policies. Ideally, the way it should work is that each individual in a group looks at all the problems and comes up with some quick notes on possible solutions. Then the group would come together and attempt to reach a consensus on each problem. Finally, the solution writing and presentation would be divvyed up between the members so alleviate some of the presentation burden. However, I personally am conflicted on group work:

\n\n
    \n
  • Positive: If done correctly, it can be a powerful way where students learn from and bounce ideas off one-another. That is definitely a good thing.
    • \n
  • Negative: Since this is my sixth time doing this course, I believe about half the groups simply divvy up the problems and dont even look at the problems not assigned to them. Ive done a bit of analysis on past semesters where Ive had a exam problem that was nearly identical to a homework problem and consistently, theres been about 25-30% of students that clearly have never seen the problem before.
    • \n
\n\n

In summary, I tend to fall of the side of discouraging group work. From what Ive seen, the strongest performing individuals are over-represented in the group of students that do the homework solo. Also I have reduced the homework burden compared to past semesters so a single person should be fine doing all the problems themselves. \nBut, I wont get rid of group homeworks all together. Like I say a lot, you guys are adults and should know what works best for you. My job is to encourage behavior that I believe will be optimal for learning, not force it.

\n\n
Earlier HW Assignment
\n

One of you made an excellent point after class that if I want to encourage starting homework early, I should post the homework on Friday instead on Monday. The argument is that if I post it on Friday, people usually have free time on the weekend to start right away while if I post on Monday, there are more things going on during the week and a lot of you wont have time to get to it till the next weekend. What a excellent criticism (I mean that sincerely) and it something I hadnt considered. SO I wont promise anything, but the deal is I will do my absolute best to post the homework by Friday midnight. The homework will cover every learned the Tuesday-Friday right before it. The due date is still the next Monday (so itll be 10 days between the assignment and submission instead of 7). The one downside is that the next homework will get assigned before the current one is due which might be a little emotionally discouraging but the benefit of allowing people to start early right after completing the requisite lectures/labs outweighs that.

\n\n
DRES
\n
    \n
  • If you have a DRES accommodation, please email me directly (not sure if sending documents over Piazza is compliant with EHR policies or not, but why risk it ). Make sure I respond that Ive recorded your accommodation! If I dont respond email again.
    • \n
  • Because of the limited staff, DRES students will take the exams at the TAC synchronously with the rest of the class. Well hammer out the details closer to MT1.
    • \n
\n\n
Labs/Discussions are the same thing
\n

Labs and discussions are the same thing. Sorry, Ive used both terms interchangeably, Ive taught this course so many times with different people, my mind keeps jumping timelines with the exact verbiage.

\n\n

\n

Additional Resources

\n
    \n
  • Jeffs Textbook - Introduction and History
    • \n
  • Jeffs - Notes on strings
    • \n
  • Sariels Lecture 1
    • \n

Lecture 1 - Course introduction and languages

\n \n\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n
Date Pre-lecture slides Post-lecture scribbles Lecture recording
\n January 17 2023\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n
\n \n  \n\n

Notes

\n\n
\n

Course policies can be found on the website ecealgo.com.

\n\n

Big Questions

\n\n

This course is focused on answering three big questions:

\n\n
    \n
  • Given infinite time, how can we group problems by their complexity (Computability-theory)
    • \n
  • Given finite time, but a problem we know is computable, how fast can we solve the problem (Algorithmic design)
    • \n
  • Given a problem which is difficult to solve, can we infer how slow/fast we can solve it by comparing it to other known problems (Reductions)
    • \n
\n\n

\n

Two types of complexity

\n

\n\n\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n
Computational ComplexityAlgorithmic Complexity
\n\n

\n

Why Languages?

\n

Problems need to be represented as languages to be comparable. A language is a set of strings and each string represents and instance of the problem (a specific set of inputs and their correponding output). For example, the problem of adding two numbers together can be represented by the language:

\n\n

Problem: Multiplying two integers together

\n\n

Language: \n\\(L_{MULT2} = \n\\begin{bmatrix}\n 1 \\times 1|1, & 1 \\times 2|2, & 1 \\times 3|3, \\ldots\\\\\n 2 \\times 1|2, & 2 \\times 2|4, & 2 \\times 3|6, \\ldots \\\\\n \\vdots & \\vdots & \\vdots \\\\\n n \\times 1|n, & n \\times 2|2n, & n \\times 3|3n, \\ldots \\\\\n\\end{bmatrix}\\)

\n\n

\n

\n

Strings and Languages

\n
    \n
  • Strings are the elements of the lenguauges. Each string represents a problem instance.
    • \n
  • A alphabet($\\Sigma$) is a finite set of symbols (example: $\\Sigma = \\{0, 1\\}$).
    • \n
\n","title":"Lecture 2 - Languages and regular expression","categories":[],"previous":{"title":"Lecture 19 - Minimum spanning trees (MSTs)","categories":[],"name":"Lec19.md","date":"2023-02-06 22:02:53 -0600","tags":[],"url":"/lectures/Lec19","collection":"lectures","path":"_lectures/Lec19.md","relative_path":"_lectures/Lec19.md","id":"/lectures/Lec19","draft":false,"placeholder":false,"back-color":"fffffa","card-link":"LecLink19","description":null,"people":null,"layout":"lecture","deliverydate":"2023-03-30","link-slides":null,"link-scribbles":null,"link-recording":null,"slug":"Lec19","ext":".md"},"content":"

Strings and Languages

\n
    \n
  • Strings are the elements of the lenguauges. Each string represents a problem instance.
    • \n
  • A alphabet($\\Sigma$) is a finite set of symbols (example: $\\Sigma = \\{0, 1\\}$).
    • \n
\n\n

Some string and set facts:

\n
\n
\n Strings:\n
    \n
  • $x \\cdot y = xy$ is the concatenation of two strings.
    • \n
  • $\\vert w \\vert$ is the length of a string
    • \n
  • $\\Sigma^n$ is the set of all strings over $\\Sigma$ of length $n$
    • \n
  • $\\Sigma^{*}$ is the set of all strings over $\\Sigma$ of all lengths
    • \n
  • $\\varepsilon$ is the empty string
    • \n
  • Subsequence of string is a subset of its characters that appear in the same order as they do in the original string
    • \n
\n
\n
\n Sets:\n
    \n
  • $\\emptyset$ is the empty set
    • \n
  • $\\\\{ \\varepsilon \\\\}$ is the non-empty set containing one element, the empty string.
    • \n
  • Concatentation of two sets is all possible pairs of elements
    • \n
\n
\n
\n\n

Terminology

\n
    \n
  • A character(a,b,c,x) is a unit of information represented by a symbol: letters, digits, whitespace
    • \n
  • A alphabet($\\Sigma$)is a set of characters
    • \n
  • A string(w) is a sequence of characters
    • \n
  • A language(A,B,C,L) is a set of strings
    • \n
  • A grammar(G) is a set of rules that defines the strings that belong to a language
    • \n
\n\n

Regular Languages

\n\n

Kleenes Theorem: A language is regular if and only if it can be obtained from finite languages by applying the three operations: union ($\\cup$), concatentation ($\\cdot$), repetition($^*$) a finite numer of times.

\n\n

Base Case:: $\\emptyset$, $\\{ \\varepsilon \\}$, $\\{a\\}$ (for each $a \\in \\Sigma$) are all regular langauges. \nInductive Step: If you can apply the above operations on the base language a

\n\n

Regular expressions

\n\n

A simple shorthand for describing a regular language. IN regular expressions:

\n\n
    \n
  • $\\emptyset$ denotes $\\emptyset$
    • \n
  • $\\varepsilon$ denotes $\\{\\varepsilon\\}$
    • \n
  • $a$ denotes $\\{a\\}$
    • \n
  • $r_1+r_2$ denotes $R_1 \\cup R_2$
    • \n
  • $r_1 \\cdot r_2$ denotes $R_1R_2$
    • \n
  • $r^*$ denotes $R^*$
    • \n
\n\n

\n

Everything tied together

\n\n

Lets look at the following problem:

\n\n

Problem: Consider the problem of a n-input AND function. The input ($x$) is a string $n$-digits long with $\\Sigma = {0,1}$ and has an output ($y$) which is the logical AND of all the elements of $x$.

\n\n

TO analyze its computational complexity, we need to formulate it as a language ($\\Sigma = \\{0, 1, \\cdot, \\vert \\}$):

\n\n\\[L_{AND_N} = \n\t\t\\begin{Bmatrix}\n\t\t\t0\\cdot|0, & 1\\cdot|1, & & \\\\\n\t\t\t0 \\cdot 0\\cdot| 0, & 0 \\cdot 1\\cdot| 0, & 1 \\cdot 0\\cdot| 0, & 1 \\cdot 1\\cdot| 1 \\\\\n\t\t\t\\vdots & \\vdots & \\vdots & \\vdots \\\\\n\t\t\t(0\\cdot)^n|0, & (0\\cdot)^{n-1}1|0, & \\ldots & (1\\cdot)^n|1 \\ldots \\\\\n\t\t\\end{Bmatrix}\\]\n\n

Then to show its one of the simplest languages there is, we represent that language as a regular expression:

\n\n\\[r_{AND_N} = \\underbrace{(0\\cdot + 1\\cdot)^* 0 (0\\cdot + 1 \\cdot)^* \\vert 0\"}_{\\text{all output 0 instances}} + \\overbrace{( 1 \\cdot)^*\\vert 1}^{\\text{all output 1 instances}}\\]\n\n

\n

Things I forgot to mention

\n\n
What is $\\varepsilon^+$
\n\n

There was a question on what $\\varepsilon^+$ (and $\\varepsilon^*$). My argument was that it should be $\\{\\varepsilon\\}$ because you always get a set out of the kleene star and:

\n\n\\[\\varepsilon^+ = \\Sigma_{n=1}^{\\infty}\\varepsilon^n = \\varepsilon^1 \\cup \\varepsilon^2 \\cup \\ldots\\]\n\n

where you have multiple strings that you can union together. However, some of you were confused because theres only strings in that equation and so shouldnt the output be a string ($\\varepsilon$ (not a set))?

\n\n

I went through a bunch of text and saw that kleene star is always applied to a set. The only time when it isnt applied to a set is when were talking about regular expressions.

\n\n

So I think you guys are right, sort of. Union is supposed to be a set operation and unioning strings together means nothing. However, the issue is regular expressions are a permanent fixture of modern computability and so when someone writes $w^*$, they dont literally mean union of $w$ with $ww$ and so on, in the mathematical sense, they mean $w^*$ in the RegEx sense and regular expressions assume that when you write $w$, you mean $\\{w\\}$. So yeah, this is my bad.

\n\n

The correct answer would be $\\{\\varepsilon\\}$ assuming a regular expression, or simply undefined in a strict mathematical interpretation.

\n\n

\n

Additional Resources

    \n
  • Jeffs - Notes on strings
    • \n
  • Jeffs notes on regular languages
    • \n
  • Sariels Lecture 2

Lecture 2 - Languages and regular expression

\n \n\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n
Date Pre-lecture slides Post-lecture scribbles Lecture recording
\n January 19 2023\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n
\n \n  \n\n

Notes

\n\n
\n

Strings and Languages

\n
    \n
  • Strings are the elements of the lenguauges. Each string represents a problem instance.
    • \n
  • A alphabet($\\Sigma$) is a finite set of symbols (example: $\\Sigma = \\{0, 1\\}$).
    • \n
\n\n

Some string and set facts:

\n
\n
\n Strings:\n
    \n
  • $x \\cdot y = xy$ is the concatenation of two strings.
    • \n
  • $\\vert w \\vert$ is the length of a string
    • \n
  • $\\Sigma^n$ is the set of all strings over $\\Sigma$ of length $n$
    • \n
  • $\\Sigma^{*}$ is the set of all strings over $\\Sigma$ of all lengths
    • \n
  • $\\varepsilon$ is the empty string
    • \n
  • Subsequence of string is a subset of its characters that appear in the same order as they do in the original string
    • \n
\n
\n
\n Sets:\n
    \n
  • $\\emptyset$ is the empty set
    • \n
  • $\\\\{ \\varepsilon \\\\}$ is the non-empty set containing one element, the empty string.
    • \n
  • Concatentation of two sets is all possible pairs of elements
    • \n
\n
\n
\n\n

Terminology

\n
    \n
  • A character(a,b,c,x) is a unit of information represented by a symbol: letters, digits, whitespace
    • \n
  • A alphabet($\\Sigma$)is a set of characters
    • \n
  • A string(w) is a sequence of characters
    • \n
  • A language(A,B,C,L) is a set of strings
    • \n
  • A grammar(G) is a set of rules that defines the strings that belong to a language
    • \n
\n\n

Regular Languages

\n\n

Kleenes Theorem: A language is regular if and only if it can be obtained from finite languages by applying the three operations: union ($\\cup$), concatentation ($\\cdot$), repetition($^*$) a finite numer of times.

\n\n

\n\n

Regular expressions

\n\n

A simple shorthand for describing a regular language. IN regular expressions:

\n\n
    \n
  • $\\emptyset$ denotes $\\emptyset$
    • \n
  • $\\varepsilon$ denotes $\\{\\varepsilon\\}$
    • \n
  • $a$ denotes $\\{a\\}$
    • \n
  • $r_1+r_2$ denotes $R_1 \\cup R_2$
    • \n
  • $r_1 \\cdot r_2$ denotes $R_1R_2$
    • \n
  • $r^*$ denotes $R^*$
    • \n
\n\n

\n

Everything tied together

\n\n

Lets look at the following problem:

\n\n

Problem: Consider the problem of a n-input AND function. The input ($x$) is a string $n$-digits long with $\\Sigma = {0,1}$ and has an output ($y$) which is the logical AND of all the elements of $x$.

\n\n

TO analyze its computational complexity, we need to formulate it as a language ($\\Sigma = \\{0, 1, \\cdot, \\vert \\}$):

\n\n\\[L_{AND_N} = \n\t\t\\begin{Bmatrix}\n\t\t\t0\\cdot|0, & 1\\cdot|1, & & \\\\\n\t\t\t0 \\cdot 0\\cdot| 0, & 0 \\cdot 1\\cdot| 0, & 1 \\cdot 0\\cdot| 0, & 1 \\cdot 1\\cdot| 1 \\\\\n\t\t\t\\vdots & \\vdots & \\vdots & \\vdots \\\\\n\t\t\t(0\\cdot)^n|0, & (0\\cdot)^{n-1}1|0, & \\ldots & (1\\cdot)^n|1 \\ldots \\\\\n\t\t\\end{Bmatrix}\\]\n\n

\n\n\\[r_{AND_N} = \\underbrace{(0\\cdot + 1\\cdot)^* 0 (0\\cdot + 1 \\cdot)^* \\vert 0\"}_{\\text{all output 0 instances}} + \\overbrace{( 1 \\cdot)^*\\vert 1}^{\\text{all output 1 instances}}\\]\n\n

\n\n

\n\n

\n\n

\n\n

Strings and Languages

\n
    \n
  • Strings are the elements of the lenguauges. Each string represents a problem instance.
    • \n
  • A alphabet($\\Sigma$) is a finite set of symbols (example: $\\Sigma = \\{0, 1\\}$).
    • \n
\n\n

Some string and set facts:

\n
\n
\n Strings:\n
    \n
  • $x \\cdot y = xy$ is the concatenation of two strings.
    • \n
  • $\\vert w \\vert$ is the length of a string
    • \n
  • $\\Sigma^n$ is the set of all strings over $\\Sigma$ of length $n$
    • \n
  • $\\Sigma^{*}$ is the set of all strings over $\\Sigma$ of all lengths
    • \n
  • $\\varepsilon$ is the empty string
    • \n
  • Subsequence of string is a subset of its characters that appear in the same order as they do in the original string
    • \n
\n
\n
\n Sets:\n
    \n
  • $\\emptyset$ is the empty set
    • \n
  • $\\\\{ \\varepsilon \\\\}$ is the non-empty set containing one element, the empty string.
    • \n
  • Concatentation of two sets is all possible pairs of elements
    • \n
\n
\n
\n\n

Terminology

\n
    \n
  • A character(a,b,c,x) is a unit of information represented by a symbol: letters, digits, whitespace
    • \n
  • A alphabet($\\Sigma$)is a set of characters
    • \n
  • A string(w) is a sequence of characters
    • \n
  • A language(A,B,C,L) is a set of strings
    • \n
  • A grammar(G) is a set of rules that defines the strings that belong to a language
    • \n
\n\n

Regular Languages

\n\n

Kleenes Theorem: A language is regular if and only if it can be obtained from finite languages by applying the three operations: union ($\\cup$), concatentation ($\\cdot$), repetition($^*$) a finite numer of times.

\n\n

Base Case:: $\\emptyset$, $\\{ \\varepsilon \\}$, $\\{a\\}$ (for each $a \\in \\Sigma$) are all regular langauges. \nInductive Step: If you can apply the above operations on the base language a

\n\n

Regular expressions

\n\n

A simple shorthand for describing a regular language. IN regular expressions:

\n\n
    \n
  • $\\emptyset$ denotes $\\emptyset$
    • \n
  • $\\varepsilon$ denotes $\\{\\varepsilon\\}$
    • \n
  • $a$ denotes $\\{a\\}$
    • \n
  • $r_1+r_2$ denotes $R_1 \\cup R_2$
    • \n
  • $r_1 \\cdot r_2$ denotes $R_1R_2$
    • \n
  • $r^*$ denotes $R^*$
    • \n
\n\n

\n

Everything tied together

\n\n

Lets look at the following problem:

\n\n

Problem: Consider the problem of a n-input AND function. The input ($x$) is a string $n$-digits long with $\\Sigma = {0,1}$ and has an output ($y$) which is the logical AND of all the elements of $x$.

\n\n

TO analyze its computational complexity, we need to formulate it as a language ($\\Sigma = \\{0, 1, \\cdot, \\vert \\}$):

\n\n\\[L_{AND_N} = \n\t\t\\begin{Bmatrix}\n\t\t\t0\\cdot|0, & 1\\cdot|1, & & \\\\\n\t\t\t0 \\cdot 0\\cdot| 0, & 0 \\cdot 1\\cdot| 0, & 1 \\cdot 0\\cdot| 0, & 1 \\cdot 1\\cdot| 1 \\\\\n\t\t\t\\vdots & \\vdots & \\vdots & \\vdots \\\\\n\t\t\t(0\\cdot)^n|0, & (0\\cdot)^{n-1}1|0, & \\ldots & (1\\cdot)^n|1 \\ldots \\\\\n\t\t\\end{Bmatrix}\\]\n\n

Then to show its one of the simplest languages there is, we represent that language as a regular expression:

\n\n\\[r_{AND_N} = \\underbrace{(0\\cdot + 1\\cdot)^* 0 (0\\cdot + 1 \\cdot)^* \\vert 0\"}_{\\text{all output 0 instances}} + \\overbrace{( 1 \\cdot)^*\\vert 1}^{\\text{all output 1 instances}}\\]\n\n

\n

Things I forgot to mention

\n\n
What is $\\varepsilon^+$
\n\n

There was a question on what $\\varepsilon^+$ (and $\\varepsilon^*$). My argument was that it should be $\\{\\varepsilon\\}$ because you always get a set out of the kleene star and:

\n\n\\[\\varepsilon^+ = \\Sigma_{n=1}^{\\infty}\\varepsilon^n = \\varepsilon^1 \\cup \\varepsilon^2 \\cup \\ldots\\]\n\n

where you have multiple strings that you can union together. However, some of you were confused because theres only strings in that equation and so shouldnt the output be a string ($\\varepsilon$ (not a set))?

\n\n

I went through a bunch of text and saw that kleene star is always applied to a set. The only time when it isnt applied to a set is when were talking about regular expressions.

\n\n

So I think you guys are right, sort of. Union is supposed to be a set operation and unioning strings together means nothing. However, the issue is regular expressions are a permanent fixture of modern computability and so when someone writes $w^*$, they dont literally mean union of $w$ with $ww$ and so on, in the mathematical sense, they mean $w^*$ in the RegEx sense and regular expressions assume that when you write $w$, you mean $\\{w\\}$. So yeah, this is my bad.

\n\n

The correct answer would be $\\{\\varepsilon\\}$ assuming a regular expression, or simply undefined in a strict mathematical interpretation.

\n\n

\n

Lecture 2 - Languages and regular expression

\n \n\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n
Date Pre-lecture slides Post-lecture scribbles Lecture recording

Notes

\n\n
\n

Strings and Languages

\n
    \n
  • Strings are the elements of the lenguauges. Each string represents a problem instance.
    • \n
  • A alphabet($\\Sigma$) is a finite set of symbols (example: $\\Sigma = \\{0, 1\\}$).
    • \n
\n\n

Some string and set facts:

\n
\n
\n Strings:\n
    \n
  • $x \\cdot y = xy$ is the concatenation of two strings.
    • \n
  • $\\vert w \\vert$ is the length of a string
    • \n
  • $\\Sigma^n$ is the set of all strings over $\\Sigma$ of length $n$
    • \n
  • $\\Sigma^{*}$ is the set of all strings over $\\Sigma$ of all lengths
    • \n
  • $\\varepsilon$ is the empty string
    • \n
  • Subsequence of string is a subset of its characters that appear in the same order as they do in the original string
    • \n
\n
\n
\n Sets:\n
    \n
  • $\\emptyset$ is the empty set
    • \n
  • $\\\\{ \\varepsilon \\\\}$ is the non-empty set containing one element, the empty string.
    • \n
  • Concatentation of two sets is all possible pairs of elements
    • \n
\n
\n
\n\n

Terminology

\n
    \n
  • A character(a,b,c,x) is a unit of information represented by a symbol: letters, digits, whitespace
    • \n
  • A alphabet($\\Sigma$)is a set of characters
    • \n
  • A string(w) is a sequence of characters
    • \n
  • A language(A,B,C,L) is a set of strings
    • \n
  • A grammar(G) is a set of rules that defines the strings that belong to a language
    • \n
\n\n

\n\n

\n\n
    \n
  • $\\emptyset$ denotes $\\emptyset$
    • \n

    • \n

    • \n

    • \n

  • \n \n Schedules\n \n
    • \n\n \n\n

Lecture 2 - Languages and regular expression

\n \n\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n
Date Pre-lecture slides Post-lecture scribbles Lecture recording
\n January 19 2023\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n
\n \n  \n\n

Notes

\n\n
\n

Strings and Languages

\n
    \n
  • Strings are the elements of the lenguauges. Each string represents a problem instance.
    • \n
  • A alphabet($\\Sigma$) is a finite set of symbols (example: $\\Sigma = \\{0, 1\\}$).
    • \n
\n\n

Some string and set facts:

\n
\n
\n Strings:\n
    \n
  • $x \\cdot y = xy$ is the concatenation of two strings.
    • \n
  • $\\vert w \\vert$ is the length of a string
    • \n
  • $\\Sigma^n$ is the set of all strings over $\\Sigma$ of length $n$
    • \n
  • $\\Sigma^{*}$ is the set of all strings over $\\Sigma$ of all lengths
    • \n
  • $\\varepsilon$ is the empty string
    • \n
  • Subsequence of string is a subset of its characters that appear in the same order as they do in the original string
    • \n
\n
\n
\n Sets:\n
    \n
  • $\\emptyset$ is the empty set
    • \n
  • $\\\\{ \\varepsilon \\\\}$ is the non-empty set containing one element, the empty string.
    • \n
  • Concatentation of two sets is all possible pairs of elements
    • \n
\n
\n
\n\n

Terminology

\n
    \n
  • A character(a,b,c,x) is a unit of information represented by a symbol: letters, digits, whitespace
    • \n
  • A alphabet($\\Sigma$)is a set of characters
    • \n
  • A string(w) is a sequence of characters
    • \n
  • A language(A,B,C,L) is a set of strings
    • \n
  • A grammar(G) is a set of rules that defines the strings that belong to a language
    • \n
\n\n

Regular Languages

\n\n

Kleenes Theorem: A language is regular if and only if it can be obtained from finite languages by applying the three operations: union ($\\cup$), concatentation ($\\cdot$), repetition($^*$) a finite numer of times.

\n\n

Base Case:: $\\emptyset$, $\\{ \\varepsilon \\}$, $\\{a\\}$ (for each $a \\in \\Sigma$) are all regular langauges. \nInductive Step: If you can apply the above operations on the base language a

\n\n

Regular expressions

\n\n

A simple shorthand for describing a regular language. IN regular expressions:

\n\n
    \n
  • $\\emptyset$ denotes $\\emptyset$
    • \n
  • $\\varepsilon$ denotes $\\{\\varepsilon\\}$
    • \n
  • $a$ denotes $\\{a\\}$
    • \n
  • $r_1+r_2$ denotes $R_1 \\cup R_2$
    • \n
  • $r_1 \\cdot r_2$ denotes $R_1R_2$
    • \n
  • $r^*$ denotes $R^*$
    • \n
\n\n

\n

Everything tied together

\n\n

Lets look at the following problem:

\n\n

Problem: Consider the problem of a n-input AND function. The input ($x$) is a string $n$-digits long with $\\Sigma = {0,1}$ and has an output ($y$) which is the logical AND of all the elements of $x$.

\n\n

TO analyze its computational complexity, we need to formulate it as a language ($\\Sigma = \\{0, 1, \\cdot, \\vert \\}$):

\n\n\\[L_{AND_N} = \n\t\t\\begin{Bmatrix}\n\t\t\t0\\cdot|0, & 1\\cdot|1, & & \\\\\n\t\t\t0 \\cdot 0\\cdot| 0, & 0 \\cdot 1\\cdot| 0, & 1 \\cdot 0\\cdot| 0, & 1 \\cdot 1\\cdot| 1 \\\\\n\t\t\t\\vdots & \\vdots & \\vdots & \\vdots \\\\\n\t\t\t(0\\cdot)^n|0, & (0\\cdot)^{n-1}1|0, & \\ldots & (1\\cdot)^n|1 \\ldots \\\\\n\t\t\\end{Bmatrix}\\]\n\n

Then to show its one of the simplest languages there is, we represent that language as a regular expression:

\n\n\\[r_{AND_N} = \\underbrace{(0\\cdot + 1\\cdot)^* 0 (0\\cdot + 1 \\cdot)^* \\vert 0\"}_{\\text{all output 0 instances}} + \\overbrace{( 1 \\cdot)^*\\vert 1}^{\\text{all output 1 instances}}\\]\n\n

\n

Things I forgot to mention

\n\n
What is $\\varepsilon^+$
\n\n

There was a question on what $\\varepsilon^+$ (and $\\varepsilon^*$). My argument was that it should be $\\{\\varepsilon\\}$ because you always get a set out of the kleene star and:

\n\n\\[\\varepsilon^+ = \\Sigma_{n=1}^{\\infty}\\varepsilon^n = \\varepsilon^1 \\cup \\varepsilon^2 \\cup \\ldots\\]\n\n

where you have multiple strings that you can union together. However, some of you were confused because theres only strings in that equation and so shouldnt the output be a string ($\\varepsilon$ (not a set))?

\n\n

I went through a bunch of text and saw that kleene star is always applied to a set. The only time when it isnt applied to a set is when were talking about regular expressions.

\n\n

So I think you guys are right, sort of. Union is supposed to be a set operation and unioning strings together means nothing. However, the issue is regular expressions are a permanent fixture of modern computability and so when someone writes $w^*$, they dont literally mean union of $w$ with $ww$ and so on, in the mathematical sense, they mean $w^*$ in the RegEx sense and regular expressions assume that when you write $w$, you mean $\\{w\\}$. So yeah, this is my bad.

\n\n

The correct answer would be $\\{\\varepsilon\\}$ assuming a regular expression, or simply undefined in a strict mathematical interpretation.

\n\n

\n

    • \n
  • Jeffs notes on regular languages
    • \n
  • Sariels Lecture 2
    • \n

Lecture 3 - Deterministic finite automata (DFAs)

\n\n \n \n\n \n \n \n\n","date":"2023-02-06 22:02:53 -0600","tags":[],"url":"/lectures/Lec3","next":{"excerpt":"\n\n","title":"Lecture 4 - Non-deterministic finite automata (NFAs)","categories":[],"previous":{"title":"Lecture 3 - Deterministic finite automata (DFAs)","categories":[],"name":"Lec3.md","date":"2023-02-06 22:02:53 -0600","tags":[],"url":"/lectures/Lec3","collection":"lectures","path":"_lectures/Lec3.md","relative_path":"_lectures/Lec3.md","id":"/lectures/Lec3","draft":false,"placeholder":false,"back-color":"faffff","card-link":"LecLink3","description":"Introduction to deterministic finite automata. We'll also discuss how to use DFAs to prove closure properties.","people":null,"layout":"lecture","deliverydate":"2023-01-24","link-slides":"/materials/lecture_slides/lec3.pdf","link-scribbles":"/materials/lecture_slides/lec3_scribbles_sp23.pdf","link-recording":"https://mediaspace.illinois.edu/media/t/1_yweasyw8/282723252","slug":"Lec3","ext":".md"},"content":"\n\n

Nondeterministic Finite Automaton(NFA)

\n\n

An NFA is a finite-state automaton that can non-deterministically transition between states.\nUnlike a DFA, an NFA can:

\n\n
    \n
  1. Transition without taking an input symbol, which is called $\\epsilon$-transition.
    2. \n
  2. Have multiple transitions for the given source state and the input symbol.
    3. \n
\n\n

Due to the properties described above, there can be multiple possible ways of transitioning between states given a single input string. \nIf there exists a way to transition from the start state to an accepting state, then the NFA accepts the input string. \nConsider the following example of an NFA.

\n\n

\n\n

Suppose the NFA received $1$ as an input string. There exists a transition from $a$ directly to the accepting state $d$, so the NFA accepts the input $1$. \nFor an input $0$, there is a transition leading to $d$, by taking the $\\epsilon$-transition to $b$ and then to $d$. \nFor an input $10$, the NFA can reach $d$ through the state $c$. Therefore, the NFA accepts three strings, $0$, $1$, and $10$.

\n\n

Formal Definition of NFA

\n\n

Formal definition of NFA is similar to that of DFA, except for the transition function. \nAn NFA $N$ is a 5-tuple $N=(\\Sigma, Q, \\delta, s, A)$, which are input alphabet, states, transition function, start state, and accepting states, respectively.\nHowever, unlike DFA, the transition function $\\delta:Q\\times \\Sigma \\rightarrow 2^Q$ is a function that maps the pairs of a state and an input symbol to the power set of $Q$.\nThis is because there can be multiple possible transitions for the given source state and the input symbol, each leading to a different state. \nThe transition function of the example NFA above can be formally described as the following.

\n\n\\[\\delta(a, \\epsilon)= \\{ b \\}\\]\n\n\\[\\delta(a, 1)=\\{c, d\\}\\]\n\n\\[\\delta(c, 0)=\\{d\\}\\]\n\n\\[\\delta(b, 0)=\\{d\\}\\]\n\n

Note that not every (state, input symbol) pairs appear in the above definition. The missing pairs are implicitly mapped to the empty set $\\emptyset$.

\n\n

Closure properties of Regular Languages

\n\n

An arbitrary NFA can be transformed to have a single accepting state as appears in the following figure.

\n\n

\n\n

The closure properties of regular languages under union, concatenation, and Kleene Star can be proved using the transformed NFAs. \nThe following figures show how the union, concatenation, Kleene star of regular languages can be constructed, given NFAs with a single accepting state.

\n\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n
Union Concatenation Kleene Star
\n \n \n \n \n \n
\n\n

Since the NFAs for the operations could be constructed, we conclude that the resulting languages are regular, and therefore the class of all regular languages is closed under the three operations. \nNote that the NFAs after applying the operations in the figures also have a single accepting state. Therefore, any combinations of unions, concatenations, and Kleene stars can be represented by recursively applying the construction method.

\n\n

Terms and concepts

\n\n
Power Set
\n\n

The power set of a set $S$, often denoted as $2^S$, is a set of all subsets of $S$. \nFor example, if $S=\\{0, 1 \\}$, then $2^S=\\{\\emptyset, \\{0\\}, \\{1\\}, \\{0,1\\} \\}$.

\n\n
$\\epsilon$-Transition
\n\n

An $\\epsilon$-transition is a transition of an NFA that does not consume an input symbol.\nIf there is an outgoing$\\epsilon$-transition from the current state of an NFA, then the NFA can choose to either take the $\\epsilon$-transition or not.

\n\n

An $\\epsilon$-reach of a state $q \\in Q$ is a set of all states that can be reached from $q$ without reading in an input symbol. \nIn the example NFA, the $\\epsilon$-reach of the state $a$ is $\\{a, b\\}$. Note that $\\epsilon$-reach of a state always contains the state itself.

\n\n
Extended Transition Function
\n\n

Describing transitions of an NFA on an input string requires applying transition function multiple times.\nThe resulting expression would contain nested transition functions like $\\delta(\\delta(\\delta(q,1),0),1)$, which can be wordy and confusing. \nAlternatively, we can define an extended transition function $\\delta^{*}$ which defines transitions on an arbitrary string, as follows.

\n\n\\[\\delta^{*}(q,\\epsilon):=\\epsilon\\text{reach}(q)\\]\n\n\\[\\delta^{*} (q, ax) := \\delta^{*} (\\delta(q,a),x)\\]\n\n

Intuitively, the extended transition function is defined by recursively applying the transition function on the current state and the leftmost symbol of the remaining input string.\nThe transition $\\delta(\\delta(\\delta(q,1),0),1)$ introduced above can now be written as $\\delta^{*}(q, 101)$. \nNote that defining the extended transition function does not change the behavior of the NFA at all. \nThe extended transition function is more like a syntactic sugar derived from the original transition function.

\n\n

\n

Lecture 4 - Non-deterministic finite automata (NFAs)

\n \n\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n

Notes

\n\n
\n\n\n

Nondeterministic Finite Automaton(NFA)

\n\n

An NFA is a finite-state automaton that can non-deterministically transition between states.\nUnlike a DFA, an NFA can:

\n\n
    \n
  1. Transition without taking an input symbol, which is called $\\epsilon$-transition.
    2. \n
  2. Have multiple transitions for the given source state and the input symbol.
    3. \n
\n\n

Due to the properties described above, there can be multiple possible ways of transitioning between states given a single input string. \nIf there exists a way to transition from the start state to an accepting state, then the NFA accepts the input string. \nConsider the following example of an NFA.

\n\n

\n\n

Suppose the NFA received $1$ as an input string. There exists a transition from $a$ directly to the accepting state $d$, so the NFA accepts the input $1$. \nFor an input $0$, there is a transition leading to $d$, by taking the $\\epsilon$-transition to $b$ and then to $d$. \nFor an input $10$, the NFA can reach $d$ through the state $c$. Therefore, the NFA accepts three strings, $0$, $1$, and $10$.

\n\n

\n\n

\n\n\\[\\delta(a, \\epsilon)= \\{ b \\}\\]\n\n\\[\\delta(a, 1)=\\{c, d\\}\\]\n\n\\[\\delta(c, 0)=\\{d\\}\\]\n\n\\[\\delta(b, 0)=\\{d\\}\\]\n\n

Note that not every (state, input symbol) pairs appear in the above definition. The missing pairs are implicitly mapped to the empty set $\\emptyset$.

\n\n

\n\n

An arbitrary NFA can be transformed to have a single accepting state as appears in the following figure.

\n\n

\n\n

\n\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n
Union Concatenation Kleene Star
\n \n \n \n \n \n
\n\n

Therefore, any combinations of unions, concatenations, and Kleene stars can be represented by recursively applying the construction method.

\n\n
Power Set
\n\n

The power set of a set $S$, often denoted as $2^S$, is a set of all subsets of $S$. \nFor example, if $S=\\{0, 1 \\}$, then $2^S=\\{\\emptyset, \\{0\\}, \\{1\\}, \\{0,1\\} \\}$.

\n\n

Nondeterministic Finite Automaton(NFA)

\n\n

An NFA is a finite-state automaton that can non-deterministically transition between states.\nUnlike a DFA, an NFA can:

\n\n
    \n
  1. Transition without taking an input symbol, which is called $\\epsilon$-transition.
    2. \n
  2. Have multiple transitions for the given source state and the input symbol.
    3. \n
\n\n

Due to the properties described above, there can be multiple possible ways of transitioning between states given a single input string. \nIf there exists a way to transition from the start state to an accepting state, then the NFA accepts the input string. \nConsider the following example of an NFA.

\n\n

\n\n

There exists a transition from $a$ directly to the accepting state $d$, so the NFA accepts the input $1$. \nFor an input $0$, there is a transition leading to $d$, by taking the $\\epsilon$-transition to $b$ and then to $d$. \nFor an input $10$, the NFA can reach $d$ through the state $c$. \n\n

\n\n\\[\\delta(a, \\epsilon)= \\{ b \\}\\]\n\n\\[\\delta(a, 1)=\\{c, d\\}\\]\n\n\\[\\delta(c, 0)=\\{d\\}\\]\n\n\\[\\delta(b, 0)=\\{d\\}\\]\n\n

Note that not every (state, input symbol) pairs appear in the above definition. The missing pairs are implicitly mapped to the empty set $\\emptyset$.

\n\n

\n\n

An arbitrary NFA can be transformed to have a single accepting state as appears in the following figure.

\n\n

\n\n

\n\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n
Union Concatenation Kleene Star
\n \n \n \n \n \n
\n\n

Terms and concepts

\n\n
Power Set
\n\n

The power set of a set $S$, often denoted as $2^S$, is a set of all subsets of $S$. \nFor example, if $S=\\{0, 1 \\}$, then $2^S=\\{\\emptyset, \\{0\\}, \\{1\\}, \\{0,1\\} \\}$.

\n\n
$\\epsilon$-Transition
\n\n

An $\\epsilon$-transition is a transition of an NFA that does not consume an input symbol.\nIf there is an outgoing$\\epsilon$-transition from the current state of an NFA, then the NFA can choose to either take the $\\epsilon$-transition or not.

\n\n

An $\\epsilon$-reach of a state $q \\in Q$ is a set of all states that can be reached from $q$ without reading in an input symbol. \nIn the example NFA, the $\\epsilon$-reach of the state $a$ is $\\{a, b\\}$. Note that $\\epsilon$-reach of a state always contains the state itself.

\n\n
Extended Transition Function
\n\n

Describing transitions of an NFA on an input string requires applying transition function multiple times.\nThe resulting expression would contain nested transition functions like $\\delta(\\delta(\\delta(q,1),0),1)$, which can be wordy and confusing. \nAlternatively, we can define an extended transition function $\\delta^{*}$ which defines transitions on an arbitrary string, as follows.

\n\n\\[\\delta^{*}(q,\\epsilon):=\\epsilon\\text{reach}(q)\\]\n\n\\[\\delta^{*} (q, ax) := \\delta^{*} (\\delta(q,a),x)\\]\n\n

Intuitively, the extended transition function is defined by recursively applying the transition function on the current state and the leftmost symbol of the remaining input string.\nThe transition $\\delta(\\delta(\\delta(q,1),0),1)$ introduced above can now be written as $\\delta^{*}(q, 101)$. \nNote that defining the extended transition function does not change the behavior of the NFA at all. \nThe extended transition function is more like a syntactic sugar derived from the original transition function.

\n\n

\n

Lecture 4 - Non-deterministic finite automata (NFAs)

\n \n\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n
Date Pre-lecture slides Post-lecture scribbles Lecture recording
\n January 26 2023\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n
\n \n  \n\n

Notes

\n\n
\n\n\n

Nondeterministic Finite Automaton(NFA)

\n\n

An NFA is a finite-state automaton that can non-deterministically transition between states.\nUnlike a DFA, an NFA can:

\n\n
    \n
  1. Transition without taking an input symbol, which is called $\\epsilon$-transition.
    2. \n
  2. Have multiple transitions for the given source state and the input symbol.
    3. \n
\n\n

Due to the properties described above, there can be multiple possible ways of transitioning between states given a single input string. \nIf there exists a way to transition from the start state to an accepting state, then the NFA accepts the input string. \nConsider the following example of an NFA.

\n\n

\n\n

Suppose the NFA received $1$ as an input string. There exists a transition from $a$ directly to the accepting state $d$, so the NFA accepts the input $1$. \nFor an input $0$, there is a transition leading to $d$, by taking the $\\epsilon$-transition to $b$ and then to $d$. \nFor an input $10$, the NFA can reach $d$ through the state $c$. Therefore, the NFA accepts three strings, $0$, $1$, and $10$.

\n\n

Formal Definition of NFA

\n\n

Formal definition of NFA is similar to that of DFA, except for the transition function. \nAn NFA $N$ is a 5-tuple $N=(\\Sigma, Q, \\delta, s, A)$, which are input alphabet, states, transition function, start state, and accepting states, respectively.\nHowever, unlike DFA, the transition function $\\delta:Q\\times \\Sigma \\rightarrow 2^Q$ is a function that maps the pairs of a state and an input symbol to the power set of $Q$.\nThis is because there can be multiple possible transitions for the given source state and the input symbol, each leading to a different state. \nThe transition function of the example NFA above can be formally described as the following.

\n\n\\[\\delta(a, \\epsilon)= \\{ b \\}\\]\n\n\\[\\delta(a, 1)=\\{c, d\\}\\]\n\n\\[\\delta(c, 0)=\\{d\\}\\]\n\n\\[\\delta(b, 0)=\\{d\\}\\]\n\n

Note that not every (state, input symbol) pairs appear in the above definition. The missing pairs are implicitly mapped to the empty set $\\emptyset$.

\n\n

Closure properties of Regular Languages

\n\n

An arbitrary NFA can be transformed to have a single accepting state as appears in the following figure.

\n\n

\n\n

The closure properties of regular languages under union, concatenation, and Kleene Star can be proved using the transformed NFAs. \nThe following figures show how the union, concatenation, Kleene star of regular languages can be constructed, given NFAs with a single accepting state.

\n\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n
Union Concatenation Kleene Star
\n \n \n \n \n \n
\n\n

Since the NFAs for the operations could be constructed, we conclude that the resulting languages are regular, and therefore the class of all regular languages is closed under the three operations. \nNote that the NFAs after applying the operations in the figures also have a single accepting state. Therefore, any combinations of unions, concatenations, and Kleene stars can be represented by recursively applying the construction method.

\n\n

Terms and concepts

\n\n
Power Set
\n\n

The power set of a set $S$, often denoted as $2^S$, is a set of all subsets of $S$. \nFor example, if $S=\\{0, 1 \\}$, then $2^S=\\{\\emptyset, \\{0\\}, \\{1\\}, \\{0,1\\} \\}$.

\n\n
$\\epsilon$-Transition
\n\n

An $\\epsilon$-transition is a transition of an NFA that does not consume an input symbol.\nIf there is an outgoing$\\epsilon$-transition from the current state of an NFA, then the NFA can choose to either take the $\\epsilon$-transition or not.

\n\n

An $\\epsilon$-reach of a state $q \\in Q$ is a set of all states that can be reached from $q$ without reading in an input symbol. \nIn the example NFA, the $\\epsilon$-reach of the state $a$ is $\\{a, b\\}$. Note that $\\epsilon$-reach of a state always contains the state itself.

\n\n
Extended Transition Function
\n\n

Describing transitions of an NFA on an input string requires applying transition function multiple times.\nThe resulting expression would contain nested transition functions like $\\delta(\\delta(\\delta(q,1),0),1)$, which can be wordy and confusing. \nAlternatively, we can define an extended transition function $\\delta^{*}$ which defines transitions on an arbitrary string, as follows.

\n\n\\[\\delta^{*}(q,\\epsilon):=\\epsilon\\text{reach}(q)\\]\n\n\\[\\delta^{*} (q, ax) := \\delta^{*} (\\delta(q,a),x)\\]\n\n

Intuitively, the extended transition function is defined by recursively applying the transition function on the current state and the leftmost symbol of the remaining input string.\nThe transition $\\delta(\\delta(\\delta(q,1),0),1)$ introduced above can now be written as $\\delta^{*}(q, 101)$. \nNote that defining the extended transition function does not change the behavior of the NFA at all. \nThe extended transition function is more like a syntactic sugar derived from the original transition function.

\n\n

\n

\n\n \n \n\n \n \n \n\n","date":"2023-02-06 22:02:53 -0600","tags":[],"url":"/lectures/Lec4","next":{"excerpt":"\n\n","title":"Lecture 5 - DFA/NFA/RegEx equivalence and grammars","categories":[],"previous":{"title":"Lecture 4 - Non-deterministic finite automata (NFAs)","categories":[],"name":"Lec4.md","date":"2023-02-06 22:02:53 -0600","tags":[],"url":"/lectures/Lec4","collection":"lectures","path":"_lectures/Lec4.md","relative_path":"_lectures/Lec4.md","id":"/lectures/Lec4","draft":false,"placeholder":false,"back-color":"faffff","card-link":"LecLink4","description":"Introduction to non-determinism. We'll talk about how it applies to automata and formalize NFA concepts/definitions.","people":null,"layout":"lecture","deliverydate":"2023-01-26","link-slides":"/materials/lecture_slides/lec4.pdf","link-scribbles":"/materials/lecture_slides/lec4_scribbles_sp23.pdf","link-recording":"https://mediaspace.illinois.edu/media/t/1_jrvgweav/282723252","slug":"Lec4","ext":".md"},"content":"\n\n

\n\n

1. DFA NFA

\n\n

All DFAs can represent any languages that are represented by NFAs. All DFAs by definition are NFAs.

\n\n

2. NFA DFA

\n\n

Consider any non-deterministic finite automata (NFA) N = $(Q, \\Sigma, \\delta, s, A)$ where :

\n Q is a finite set whose elements are called states,
\n $\\Sigma$ is a finite set called the input alphabet,
\n $\\delta$ : Q $\\Sigma$ $\\cup$ {$\\epsilon$} P(Q) is the transition function (here\nP(Q) is the power set of Q),
\n s Q is the start state,
\n A Q is the set of accepting/final states.

\n\n

$\\delta$(q, a) for a $\\in$ $\\Sigma$ $\\cup$ {$\\epsilon$} is a subset of Q a set of states.

\n\n

An equivalent DFA D = $(Q, \\Sigma, \\delta, s, A)$ can be constructed using the Subset State Construction such that:

\n\n

$Q = P(Q)$
\n \\(s' = \\epsilon reach(s) = \\delta^{*}(s,\\epsilon)\\)
\n $A = { X \\subseteq Q | X \\cap A \\neq \\emptyset}$
\n $\\delta(X, a) = \\bigcup\\limits_{q \\in X} \\delta^{*} (q,a) for each X \\subseteq Q , a \\in \\Sigma$

\n\n

3. Regular Expressions NFA

\n\n

Any regular expression can be converted to an NFA using the Thompsons Algorithm as follows:

\n\n \n \n \n \n \n \n
\n \n \n \n \n \n
\n


\nExample: Construct a NFA for (101 + 010)
\n

\n

4. DFA Regular Expressions

\n\n

A Regular expression can be obtained from a DFA using two methods.

\n\n

A. State Removal Method

\n\n

If q1 = $\\delta$(q0, x) and q2 = $\\delta$(q1, y), then q2 = $\\delta$(q1, y) = $\\delta$($\\delta$(q0, x), y) = $\\delta$(q0, xy). This way, we can eliminate state q1.

\n\n

\n\n

Example:

\n\n

\n\n

Therefore, the resulting regular expression for the given DFA is $(01 + (1 + 00)(10)^{}(0 + 11))^{}$

\n\n

B. Algebraic Method

\n\n

This method involves treating transition functions as algebraic expressions. That is, $q_1 = \\delta(q_0, x)$ can be written as $q_1 = q_0x$ and the resulting expressions can be solved for the accepting state.

\n\n

Example: Convert the following DFA to regular expression using Algebraic Method.

\n\n

\n\n

Writing down transitions as algebraic functions :
\n $q_{0} = \\epsilon + q_{1}1 + q_{2}0$
\n $q_{1} = q_{0}0$
\n $q_{2} = q_{0}1$
\n $q_{3} = q_{1}0 + q_{2}1 + q_{3}(0 + 1)$

\n\n

Now we simple solve the system of equations for $q_{0}$:
\n $q_{0} = \\epsilon + q_{1}1 + q_{2}0$
\n=> $q_{0} = \\epsilon + q_{0}01 + q_{0}10$
\n=> $q_{0} = \\epsilon + q_{0}(01 + 10)$

\n\n

Make use of Theorem (Ardens Theorem) that states $R = Q + RP = QP^{}$

\n\n

=> $q_{0} = \\epsilon(01 + 10)^{} = (01 + 10)^{}$

\n\n

5. NFA Regular Expressions

\n\n

Any NFA can be converted to regular expressions using the same two methods as listed above :

\n\n

Algebraic Method - Treat transition functions as algebraic functions and solve for accepting state.

\n\n

State Removal Method - Normalize the NFA to have an isolated starting and ending state and then follow the same process as listed above.

\n\n

Example:

\n\n

\n

\n\n

6. Regular Expressions DFA

\n\n

To convert Regular Expressions to DFA we can make use of the Brzozowski derivative, where ($u^{1}$ S) of a set S of strings and a string u is the set of strings obtainable from a string in S by cutting of the prefix u.

\n\n

Example: To construct language $R = (ab + c)^{*}$\n

\n
\n
\n R \n
\n
\n $a^{-1}R$ \n
\n
\n $b^{-1}R$ \n
\n
\n $c^{-1}R$ \n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n $q_0 = \\epsilon^{-1}R = (ab+c)^{*}$\n
\n
\n $b(ab + c)^{*}$\n
\n
\n $\\emptyset$ \n
\n
\n $(ab + c)^{*}$ \n
\n
\n
\n
\n $q_1 = b(ab + c)^{*}$\n
\n
\n $\\emptyset$ \n
\n
\n $(ab + c)^{*}$\n
\n
\n $\\emptyset$ \n
\n
\n
\n
\n $q_2 = \\emptyset$\n
\n
\n $\\emptyset$ \n
\n
\n $\\emptyset$ \n
\n
\n $\\emptyset$ \n
\n
\n


\n\n

Lecture 5 - DFA/NFA/RegEx equivalence and grammars

\n \n\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n

\n January 31 2023\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n

Notes

\n\n
\n\n\n

\n\n

1. DFA NFA

\n\n

All DFAs can represent any languages that are represented by NFAs. All DFAs by definition are NFAs.

\n\n

2. NFA DFA

\n\n

Consider any non-deterministic finite automata (NFA) N = $(Q, \\Sigma, \\delta, s, A)$ where :

\n Q is a finite set whose elements are called states,
\n $\\Sigma$ is a finite set called the input alphabet,
\n $\\delta$ : Q $\\Sigma$ $\\cup$ {$\\epsilon$} P(Q) is the transition function (here\nP(Q) is the power set of Q),
\n s Q is the start state,
\n A Q is the set of accepting/final states.

\n\n

\n \\(s' = \\epsilon reach(s) = \\delta^{*}(s,\\epsilon)\\)
\n $A = { X \\subseteq Q | X \\cap A \\neq \\emptyset}$
\n $\\delta(X, a) = \\bigcup\\limits_{q \\in X} \\delta^{*} (q,a) for each X \\subseteq Q , a \\in \\Sigma$

\n\n

\n\n

\n\n \n \n \n \n \n \n
\n \n \n \n \n \n

\nExample: Construct a NFA for (101 + 010)

\n\n

\n\n

\n\n

Example:

\n\n

\n\n

\n\n

\n\n

\n\n

\n $q_{3} = q_{1}0 + q_{2}1 + q_{3}(0 + 1)$

\n=> $q_{0} = \\epsilon + q_{0}(01 + 10)$

\n\n

Make use of Theorem (Ardens Theorem) that states $R = Q + RP = QP^{}$

\n\n

=> $q_{0} = \\epsilon(01 + 10)^{} = (01 + 10)^{}$

\n\n

\n\n

\n\n

Nondeterministic Finite Automaton(NFA)

\n\n

An NFA is a finite-state automaton that can non-deterministically transition between states.\nUnlike a DFA, an NFA can:

\n\n
    \n
  1. Transition without taking an input symbol, which is called $\\epsilon$-transition.
    2. \n
  2. Have multiple transitions for the given source state and the input symbol.
    3. \n
\n\n

Due to the properties described above, there can be multiple possible ways of transitioning between states given a single input string. \nIf there exists a way to transition from the start state to an accepting state, then the NFA accepts the input string. \nConsider the following example of an NFA.

\n\n

\n\n

Suppose the NFA received $1$ as an input string. There exists a transition from $a$ directly to the accepting state $d$, so the NFA accepts the input $1$. \nFor an input $0$, there is a transition leading to $d$, by taking the $\\epsilon$-transition to $b$ and then to $d$. \nFor an input $10$, the NFA can reach $d$ through the state $c$. Therefore, the NFA accepts three strings, $0$, $1$, and $10$.

\n\n

Formal Definition of NFA

\n\n

Formal definition of NFA is similar to that of DFA, except for the transition function. \nAn NFA $N$ is a 5-tuple $N=(\\Sigma, Q, \\delta, s, A)$, which are input alphabet, states, transition function, start state, and accepting states, respectively.\nHowever, unlike DFA, the transition function $\\delta:Q\\times \\Sigma \\rightarrow 2^Q$ is a function that maps the pairs of a state and an input symbol to the power set of $Q$.\nThis is because there can be multiple possible transitions for the given source state and the input symbol, each leading to a different state. \nThe transition function of the example NFA above can be formally described as the following.

\n\n\\[\\delta(a, \\epsilon)= \\{ b \\}\\]\n\n\\[\\delta(a, 1)=\\{c, d\\}\\]\n\n\\[\\delta(c, 0)=\\{d\\}\\]\n\n\\[\\delta(b, 0)=\\{d\\}\\]\n\n

Note that not every (state, input symbol) pairs appear in the above definition. The missing pairs are implicitly mapped to the empty set $\\emptyset$.

\n\n

Closure properties of Regular Languages

\n\n

An arbitrary NFA can be transformed to have a single accepting state as appears in the following figure.

\n\n

\n\n

The closure properties of regular languages under union, concatenation, and Kleene Star can be proved using the transformed NFAs. \nThe following figures show how the union, concatenation, Kleene star of regular languages can be constructed, given NFAs with a single accepting state.

\n\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n
Union Concatenation Kleene Star
\n \n \n \n \n \n
\n\n

Since the NFAs for the operations could be constructed, we conclude that the resulting languages are regular, and therefore the class of all regular languages is closed under the three operations. \nNote that the NFAs after applying the operations in the figures also have a single accepting state. Therefore, any combinations of unions, concatenations, and Kleene stars can be represented by recursively applying the construction method.

\n\n

Terms and concepts

\n\n
Power Set
\n\n

The power set of a set $S$, often denoted as $2^S$, is a set of all subsets of $S$. \nFor example, if $S=\\{0, 1 \\}$, then $2^S=\\{\\emptyset, \\{0\\}, \\{1\\}, \\{0,1\\} \\}$.

\n\n
$\\epsilon$-Transition
\n\n

An $\\epsilon$-transition is a transition of an NFA that does not consume an input symbol.\nIf there is an outgoing$\\epsilon$-transition from the current state of an NFA, then the NFA can choose to either take the $\\epsilon$-transition or not.

\n\n

An $\\epsilon$-reach of a state $q \\in Q$ is a set of all states that can be reached from $q$ without reading in an input symbol. \nIn the example NFA, the $\\epsilon$-reach of the state $a$ is $\\{a, b\\}$. Note that $\\epsilon$-reach of a state always contains the state itself.

\n\n
Extended Transition Function
\n\n

Describing transitions of an NFA on an input string requires applying transition function multiple times.\nThe resulting expression would contain nested transition functions like $\\delta(\\delta(\\delta(q,1),0),1)$, which can be wordy and confusing. \nAlternatively, we can define an extended transition function $\\delta^{*}$ which defines transitions on an arbitrary string, as follows.

\n\n\\[\\delta^{*}(q,\\epsilon):=\\epsilon\\text{reach}(q)\\]\n\n\\[\\delta^{*} (q, ax) := \\delta^{*} (\\delta(q,a),x)\\]\n\n

Intuitively, the extended transition function is defined by recursively applying the transition function on the current state and the leftmost symbol of the remaining input string.\nThe transition $\\delta(\\delta(\\delta(q,1),0),1)$ introduced above can now be written as $\\delta^{*}(q, 101)$. \nNote that defining the extended transition function does not change the behavior of the NFA at all. \nThe extended transition function is more like a syntactic sugar derived from the original transition function.

\n\n

\n

Lecture 4 - Non-deterministic finite automata (NFAs)

\n \n\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n
Date Pre-lecture slides Post-lecture scribbles Lecture recording
\n January 26 2023\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n
\n \n  \n\n

Notes

\n\n
\n\n\n

Nondeterministic Finite Automaton(NFA)

\n\n

An NFA is a finite-state automaton that can non-deterministically transition between states.\nUnlike a DFA, an NFA can:

\n\n
    \n
  1. Transition without taking an input symbol, which is called $\\epsilon$-transition.
    2. \n
  2. Have multiple transitions for the given source state and the input symbol.
    3. \n
\n\n

Due to the properties described above, there can be multiple possible ways of transitioning between states given a single input string. \nIf there exists a way to transition from the start state to an accepting state, then the NFA accepts the input string. \nConsider the following example of an NFA.

\n\n

\n\n

Suppose the NFA received $1$ as an input string. There exists a transition from $a$ directly to the accepting state $d$, so the NFA accepts the input $1$. \nFor an input $0$, there is a transition leading to $d$, by taking the $\\epsilon$-transition to $b$ and then to $d$. \nFor an input $10$, the NFA can reach $d$ through the state $c$. Therefore, the NFA accepts three strings, $0$, $1$, and $10$.

\n\n

Formal Definition of NFA

\n\n

Formal definition of NFA is similar to that of DFA, except for the transition function. \nAn NFA $N$ is a 5-tuple $N=(\\Sigma, Q, \\delta, s, A)$, which are input alphabet, states, transition function, start state, and accepting states, respectively.\nHowever, unlike DFA, the transition function $\\delta:Q\\times \\Sigma \\rightarrow 2^Q$ is a function that maps the pairs of a state and an input symbol to the power set of $Q$.\nThis is because there can be multiple possible transitions for the given source state and the input symbol, each leading to a different state. \nThe transition function of the example NFA above can be formally described as the following.

\n\n\\[\\delta(a, \\epsilon)= \\{ b \\}\\]\n\n\\[\\delta(a, 1)=\\{c, d\\}\\]\n\n\\[\\delta(c, 0)=\\{d\\}\\]\n\n\\[\\delta(b, 0)=\\{d\\}\\]\n\n

Note that not every (state, input symbol) pairs appear in the above definition. The missing pairs are implicitly mapped to the empty set $\\emptyset$.

\n\n

Closure properties of Regular Languages

\n\n

An arbitrary NFA can be transformed to have a single accepting state as appears in the following figure.

\n\n

\n\n

The closure properties of regular languages under union, concatenation, and Kleene Star can be proved using the transformed NFAs. \nThe following figures show how the union, concatenation, Kleene star of regular languages can be constructed, given NFAs with a single accepting state.

\n\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n
Union Concatenation Kleene Star
\n \n \n \n \n \n
\n\n

Since the NFAs for the operations could be constructed, we conclude that the resulting languages are regular, and therefore the class of all regular languages is closed under the three operations. \nNote that the NFAs after applying the operations in the figures also have a single accepting state. Therefore, any combinations of unions, concatenations, and Kleene stars can be represented by recursively applying the construction method.

\n\n

Terms and concepts

\n\n
Power Set
\n\n

The power set of a set $S$, often denoted as $2^S$, is a set of all subsets of $S$. \nFor example, if $S=\\{0, 1 \\}$, then $2^S=\\{\\emptyset, \\{0\\}, \\{1\\}, \\{0,1\\} \\}$.

\n\n
$\\epsilon$-Transition
\n\n

An $\\epsilon$-transition is a transition of an NFA that does not consume an input symbol.\nIf there is an outgoing$\\epsilon$-transition from the current state of an NFA, then the NFA can choose to either take the $\\epsilon$-transition or not.

\n\n

An $\\epsilon$-reach of a state $q \\in Q$ is a set of all states that can be reached from $q$ without reading in an input symbol. \nIn the example NFA, the $\\epsilon$-reach of the state $a$ is $\\{a, b\\}$. Note that $\\epsilon$-reach of a state always contains the state itself.

\n\n
Extended Transition Function
\n\n

Describing transitions of an NFA on an input string requires applying transition function multiple times.\nThe resulting expression would contain nested transition functions like $\\delta(\\delta(\\delta(q,1),0),1)$, which can be wordy and confusing. \nAlternatively, we can define an extended transition function $\\delta^{*}$ which defines transitions on an arbitrary string, as follows.

\n\n\\[\\delta^{*}(q,\\epsilon):=\\epsilon\\text{reach}(q)\\]\n\n\\[\\delta^{*} (q, ax) := \\delta^{*} (\\delta(q,a),x)\\]\n\n

Intuitively, the extended transition function is defined by recursively applying the transition function on the current state and the leftmost symbol of the remaining input string.\nThe transition $\\delta(\\delta(\\delta(q,1),0),1)$ introduced above can now be written as $\\delta^{*}(q, 101)$. \nNote that defining the extended transition function does not change the behavior of the NFA at all. \nThe extended transition function is more like a syntactic sugar derived from the original transition function.

\n\n

We'll talk about how it applies to automata and formalize NFA concepts/definitions.","people":null,"layout":"lecture","deliverydate":"2023-01-26","link-slides":"/materials/lecture_slides/lec4.pdf","link-scribbles":"/materials/lecture_slides/lec4_scribbles_sp23.pdf","link-recording":"https://mediaspace.illinois.edu/media/t/1_jrvgweav/282723252","slug":"Lec4","ext":".md"},"content":"\n\n

\n\n

1. DFA NFA

\n\n

All DFAs can represent any languages that are represented by NFAs. All DFAs by definition are NFAs.

\n\n

2. NFA DFA

\n\n

Consider any non-deterministic finite automata (NFA) N = $(Q, \\Sigma, \\delta, s, A)$ where :

\n Q is a finite set whose elements are called states,
\n $\\Sigma$ is a finite set called the input alphabet,
\n $\\delta$ : Q $\\Sigma$ $\\cup$ {$\\epsilon$} P(Q) is the transition function (here\nP(Q) is the power set of Q),
\n s Q is the start state,
\n A Q is the set of accepting/final states.

\n\n

$\\delta$(q, a) for a $\\in$ $\\Sigma$ $\\cup$ {$\\epsilon$} is a subset of Q a set of states.

\n\n

An equivalent DFA D = $(Q, \\Sigma, \\delta, s, A)$ can be constructed using the Subset State Construction such that:

\n\n

$Q = P(Q)$
\n \\(s' = \\epsilon reach(s) = \\delta^{*}(s,\\epsilon)\\)
\n $A = { X \\subseteq Q | X \\cap A \\neq \\emptyset}$
\n $\\delta(X, a) = \\bigcup\\limits_{q \\in X} \\delta^{*} (q,a) for each X \\subseteq Q , a \\in \\Sigma$

\n\n

3. Regular Expressions NFA

\n\n

Any regular expression can be converted to an NFA using the Thompsons Algorithm as follows:

\n\n \n \n \n \n \n \n
\n \n \n \n \n \n
\n


\nExample: Construct a NFA for (101 + 010)
\n

\n

4. DFA Regular Expressions

\n\n

A Regular expression can be obtained from a DFA using two methods.

\n\n

A. State Removal Method

\n\n

If q1 = $\\delta$(q0, x) and q2 = $\\delta$(q1, y), then q2 = $\\delta$(q1, y) = $\\delta$($\\delta$(q0, x), y) = $\\delta$(q0, xy). This way, we can eliminate state q1.

\n\n

\n\n

Example:

\n\n

\n\n

Therefore, the resulting regular expression for the given DFA is $(01 + (1 + 00)(10)^{}(0 + 11))^{}$

\n\n

B. Algebraic Method

\n\n

This method involves treating transition functions as algebraic expressions. That is, $q_1 = \\delta(q_0, x)$ can be written as $q_1 = q_0x$ and the resulting expressions can be solved for the accepting state.

\n\n

Example: Convert the following DFA to regular expression using Algebraic Method.

\n\n

\n\n

Writing down transitions as algebraic functions :
\n $q_{0} = \\epsilon + q_{1}1 + q_{2}0$
\n $q_{1} = q_{0}0$
\n $q_{2} = q_{0}1$
\n $q_{3} = q_{1}0 + q_{2}1 + q_{3}(0 + 1)$

\n\n

Now we simple solve the system of equations for $q_{0}$:
\n $q_{0} = \\epsilon + q_{1}1 + q_{2}0$
\n=> $q_{0} = \\epsilon + q_{0}01 + q_{0}10$
\n=> $q_{0} = \\epsilon + q_{0}(01 + 10)$

\n\n

Make use of Theorem (Ardens Theorem) that states $R = Q + RP = QP^{}$

\n\n

=> $q_{0} = \\epsilon(01 + 10)^{} = (01 + 10)^{}$

\n\n

5. NFA Regular Expressions

\n\n

Any NFA can be converted to regular expressions using the same two methods as listed above :

\n\n

Algebraic Method - Treat transition functions as algebraic functions and solve for accepting state.

\n\n

State Removal Method - Normalize the NFA to have an isolated starting and ending state and then follow the same process as listed above.

\n\n

Example:

\n\n

\n

\n\n

6. Regular Expressions DFA

\n\n

To convert Regular Expressions to DFA we can make use of the Brzozowski derivative, where ($u^{1}$ S) of a set S of strings and a string u is the set of strings obtainable from a string in S by cutting of the prefix u.

\n\n

Example: To construct language $R = (ab + c)^{*}$\n

\n
\n
\n R \n
\n
\n $a^{-1}R$ \n
\n
\n $b^{-1}R$ \n
\n
\n $c^{-1}R$ \n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n $q_0 = \\epsilon^{-1}R = (ab+c)^{*}$\n
\n
\n $b(ab + c)^{*}$\n
\n
\n $\\emptyset$ \n
\n
\n $(ab + c)^{*}$ \n
\n
\n
\n
\n $q_1 = b(ab + c)^{*}$\n
\n
\n $\\emptyset$ \n
\n
\n $(ab + c)^{*}$\n
\n
\n $\\emptyset$ \n
\n
\n
\n
\n $q_2 = \\emptyset$\n
\n
\n $\\emptyset$ \n
\n
\n $\\emptyset$ \n
\n
\n $\\emptyset$ \n
\n
\n


\n\n

Lecture 5 - DFA/NFA/RegEx equivalence and grammars

\n \n\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n
Date Pre-lecture slides Post-lecture scribbles Lecture recording
\n January 31 2023\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n

Notes

\n\n
\n\n\n

\n\n

\n\n

All DFAs can represent any languages that are represented by NFAs. All DFAs by definition are NFAs.

\n\n

2. NFA DFA

\n\n

Consider any non-deterministic finite automata (NFA) N = $(Q, \\Sigma, \\delta, s, A)$ where :

\n Q is a finite set whose elements are called states,
\n $\\Sigma$ is a finite set called the input alphabet,

\n\n

\n \\(s' = \\epsilon reach(s) = \\delta^{*}(s,\\epsilon)\\)

\n $\\delta(X, a) = \\bigcup\\limits_{q \\in X} \\delta^{*} (q,a) for each X \\subseteq Q , a \\in \\Sigma$

\n\n

\n\n

\n\n

Example:

\n\n

\n\n

\n\n

\n\n

\n $q_{0} = \\epsilon + q_{1}1 + q_{2}0$
\n $q_{1} = q_{0}0$
\n $q_{2} = q_{0}1$
\n $q_{3} = q_{1}0 + q_{2}1 + q_{3}(0 + 1)$

\n\n

\n $q_{0} = \\epsilon + q_{1}1 + q_{2}0$
\n=> $q_{0} = \\epsilon + q_{0}01 + q_{0}10$
\n=> $q_{0} = \\epsilon + q_{0}(01 + 10)$

\n\n

Make use of Theorem (Ardens Theorem) that states $R = Q + RP = QP^{}$

\n\n

=> $q_{0} = \\epsilon(01 + 10)^{} = (01 + 10)^{}$

\n\n

5. NFA Regular Expressions

\n\n

Any NFA can be converted to regular expressions using the same two methods as listed above :

\n\n

Algebraic Method - Treat transition functions as algebraic functions and solve for accepting state.

\n\n

State Removal Method - Normalize the NFA to have an isolated starting and ending state and then follow the same process as listed above.

\n\n

Example:

\n\n

\n\n

6. Regular Expressions DFA

\n\n

To convert Regular Expressions to DFA we can make use of the Brzozowski derivative, where ($u^{1}$ S) of a set S of strings and a string u is the set of strings obtainable from a string in S by cutting of the prefix u.

\n\n

\n

\n

\n
\n $c^{-1}R$ \n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n $q_0 = \\epsilon^{-1}R = (ab+c)^{*}$\n
\n
\n $b(ab + c)^{*}$\n
\n
\n $\\emptyset$ \n

\n
\n

\n $q_1 = b(ab + c)^{*}$\n
\n

\n
\n $\\emptyset$ \n

Lecture 6 - Non-regularity and fooling sets
