\n","title":"Lecture 6 - Non-regularity and fooling sets","categories":[],"previous":{"excerpt":"\n\n","title":"Lecture 5 - DFA/NFA/RegEx equivalence and grammars","categories":[],"previous":{"title":"Lecture 4 - Non-deterministic finite automata (NFAs)","categories":[],"name":"Lec4.md","date":"2023-02-06 22:02:53 -0600","tags":[],"url":"/lectures/Lec4","collection":"lectures","path":"_lectures/Lec4.md","relative_path":"_lectures/Lec4.md","id":"/lectures/Lec4","draft":false,"placeholder":false,"back-color":"faffff","card-link":"LecLink4","description":"Introduction to non-determinism. We'll talk about how it applies to automata and formalize NFA concepts/definitions.","people":null,"layout":"lecture","deliverydate":"2023-01-26","link-slides":"/materials/lecture_slides/lec4.pdf","link-scribbles":"/materials/lecture_slides/lec4_scribbles_sp23.pdf","link-recording":"https://mediaspace.illinois.edu/media/t/1_jrvgweav/282723252","slug":"Lec4","ext":".md"},"content":"\n\n

\n\n

1. DFA NFA

\n\n

All DFAs can represent any languages that are represented by NFAs. All DFAs by definition are NFAs.

\n\n

2. NFA DFA

\n\n

Consider any non-deterministic finite automata (NFA) N = $(Q, \\Sigma, \\delta, s, A)$ where :

\n Q is a finite set whose elements are called states,
\n $\\Sigma$ is a finite set called the input alphabet,
\n $\\delta$ : Q $\\Sigma$ $\\cup$ {$\\epsilon$} P(Q) is the transition function (here\nP(Q) is the power set of Q),
\n s Q is the start state,
\n A Q is the set of accepting/final states.

\n\n

$\\delta$(q, a) for a $\\in$ $\\Sigma$ $\\cup$ {$\\epsilon$} is a subset of Q a set of states.

\n\n

An equivalent DFA D = $(Q, \\Sigma, \\delta, s, A)$ can be constructed using the Subset State Construction such that:

\n\n

$Q = P(Q)$
\n \\(s' = \\epsilon reach(s) = \\delta^{*}(s,\\epsilon)\\)
\n $A = { X \\subseteq Q | X \\cap A \\neq \\emptyset}$
\n $\\delta(X, a) = \\bigcup\\limits_{q \\in X} \\delta^{*} (q,a) for each X \\subseteq Q , a \\in \\Sigma$

\n\n

3. Regular Expressions NFA

\n\n

Any regular expression can be converted to an NFA using the Thompsons Algorithm as follows:

\n\n \n \n \n \n \n \n
\n \n \n \n \n \n
\n


\nExample: Construct a NFA for (101 + 010)
\n

\n

4. DFA Regular Expressions

\n\n

A Regular expression can be obtained from a DFA using two methods.

\n\n

A. State Removal Method

\n\n

If q1 = $\\delta$(q0, x) and q2 = $\\delta$(q1, y), then q2 = $\\delta$(q1, y) = $\\delta$($\\delta$(q0, x), y) = $\\delta$(q0, xy). This way, we can eliminate state q1.

\n\n

\n\n

Example:

\n\n

\n\n

Therefore, the resulting regular expression for the given DFA is $(01 + (1 + 00)(10)^{}(0 + 11))^{}$

\n\n

B. Algebraic Method

\n\n

This method involves treating transition functions as algebraic expressions. That is, $q_1 = \\delta(q_0, x)$ can be written as $q_1 = q_0x$ and the resulting expressions can be solved for the accepting state.

\n\n

Example: Convert the following DFA to regular expression using Algebraic Method.

\n\n

\n\n

Writing down transitions as algebraic functions :
\n $q_{0} = \\epsilon + q_{1}1 + q_{2}0$
\n $q_{1} = q_{0}0$
\n $q_{2} = q_{0}1$
\n $q_{3} = q_{1}0 + q_{2}1 + q_{3}(0 + 1)$

\n\n

Now we simple solve the system of equations for $q_{0}$:
\n $q_{0} = \\epsilon + q_{1}1 + q_{2}0$
\n=> $q_{0} = \\epsilon + q_{0}01 + q_{0}10$
\n=> $q_{0} = \\epsilon + q_{0}(01 + 10)$

\n\n

Make use of Theorem (Ardens Theorem) that states $R = Q + RP = QP^{}$

\n\n

=> $q_{0} = \\epsilon(01 + 10)^{} = (01 + 10)^{}$

\n\n

5. NFA Regular Expressions

\n\n

Any NFA can be converted to regular expressions using the same two methods as listed above :

\n\n

Algebraic Method - Treat transition functions as algebraic functions and solve for accepting state.

\n\n

State Removal Method - Normalize the NFA to have an isolated starting and ending state and then follow the same process as listed above.

\n\n

Example:

\n\n

\n

\n\n

6. Regular Expressions DFA

\n\n

To convert Regular Expressions to DFA we can make use of the Brzozowski derivative, where ($u^{1}$ S) of a set S of strings and a string u is the set of strings obtainable from a string in S by cutting of the prefix u.

\n\n

Example: To construct language $R = (ab + c)^{*}$\n

\n
\n
\n R \n
\n
\n $a^{-1}R$ \n
\n
\n $b^{-1}R$ \n
\n
\n $c^{-1}R$ \n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n $q_0 = \\epsilon^{-1}R = (ab+c)^{*}$\n
\n
\n $b(ab + c)^{*}$\n
\n
\n $\\emptyset$ \n
\n
\n $(ab + c)^{*}$ \n
\n
\n
\n
\n $q_1 = b(ab + c)^{*}$\n
\n
\n $\\emptyset$ \n
\n
\n $(ab + c)^{*}$\n
\n
\n $\\emptyset$ \n
\n
\n
\n
\n $q_2 = \\emptyset$\n
\n
\n $\\emptyset$ \n
\n
\n $\\emptyset$ \n
\n
\n $\\emptyset$ \n
\n
\n


\n\n

Lecture 5 - DFA/NFA/RegEx equivalence and grammars

\n \n\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n
Date Pre-lecture slides Post-lecture scribbles Lecture recording
\n January 31 2023\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n
\n \n  \n\n

Notes

\n\n
\n\n\n

\n\n

1. DFA NFA

\n\n

All DFAs can represent any languages that are represented by NFAs. All DFAs by definition are NFAs.

\n\n

2. NFA DFA

\n\n

Consider any non-deterministic finite automata (NFA) N = $(Q, \\Sigma, \\delta, s, A)$ where :

\n Q is a finite set whose elements are called states,
\n $\\Sigma$ is a finite set called the input alphabet,
\n $\\delta$ : Q $\\Sigma$ $\\cup$ {$\\epsilon$} P(Q) is the transition function (here\nP(Q) is the power set of Q),
\n s Q is the start state,
\n A Q is the set of accepting/final states.

\n\n

$\\delta$(q, a) for a $\\in$ $\\Sigma$ $\\cup$ {$\\epsilon$} is a subset of Q a set of states.

\n\n

An equivalent DFA D = $(Q, \\Sigma, \\delta, s, A)$ can be constructed using the Subset State Construction such that:

\n\n

$Q = P(Q)$
\n \\(s' = \\epsilon reach(s) = \\delta^{*}(s,\\epsilon)\\)
\n $A = { X \\subseteq Q | X \\cap A \\neq \\emptyset}$
\n $\\delta(X, a) = \\bigcup\\limits_{q \\in X} \\delta^{*} (q,a) for each X \\subseteq Q , a \\in \\Sigma$

\n\n

3. Regular Expressions NFA

\n\n

Any regular expression can be converted to an NFA using the Thompsons Algorithm as follows:

\n\n \n \n \n \n \n \n
\n \n \n \n \n \n
\n


\nExample: Construct a NFA for (101 + 010)
\n

\n

4. DFA Regular Expressions

\n\n

A Regular expression can be obtained from a DFA using two methods.

\n\n

A. State Removal Method

\n\n

If q1 = $\\delta$(q0, x) and q2 = $\\delta$(q1, y), then q2 = $\\delta$(q1, y) = $\\delta$($\\delta$(q0, x), y) = $\\delta$(q0, xy). This way, we can eliminate state q1.

\n\n

\n\n

Example:

\n\n

\n\n

Therefore, the resulting regular expression for the given DFA is $(01 + (1 + 00)(10)^{}(0 + 11))^{}$

\n\n

B. Algebraic Method

\n\n

This method involves treating transition functions as algebraic expressions. That is, $q_1 = \\delta(q_0, x)$ can be written as $q_1 = q_0x$ and the resulting expressions can be solved for the accepting state.

\n\n

Example: Convert the following DFA to regular expression using Algebraic Method.

\n\n

\n\n

Writing down transitions as algebraic functions :
\n $q_{0} = \\epsilon + q_{1}1 + q_{2}0$
\n $q_{1} = q_{0}0$
\n $q_{2} = q_{0}1$
\n $q_{3} = q_{1}0 + q_{2}1 + q_{3}(0 + 1)$

\n\n

Now we simple solve the system of equations for $q_{0}$:
\n $q_{0} = \\epsilon + q_{1}1 + q_{2}0$
\n=> $q_{0} = \\epsilon + q_{0}01 + q_{0}10$
\n=> $q_{0} = \\epsilon + q_{0}(01 + 10)$

\n\n

Make use of Theorem (Ardens Theorem) that states $R = Q + RP = QP^{}$

\n\n

=> $q_{0} = \\epsilon(01 + 10)^{} = (01 + 10)^{}$

\n\n

5. NFA Regular Expressions

\n\n

Any NFA can be converted to regular expressions using the same two methods as listed above :

\n\n

Algebraic Method - Treat transition functions as algebraic functions and solve for accepting state.

\n\n

State Removal Method - Normalize the NFA to have an isolated starting and ending state and then follow the same process as listed above.

\n\n

Example:

\n\n

\n

\n\n

6. Regular Expressions DFA

\n\n

To convert Regular Expressions to DFA we can make use of the Brzozowski derivative, where ($u^{1}$ S) of a set S of strings and a string u is the set of strings obtainable from a string in S by cutting of the prefix u.

\n\n

Example: To construct language $R = (ab + c)^{*}$\n

\n
\n
\n R \n
\n
\n $a^{-1}R$ \n
\n
\n $b^{-1}R$ \n
\n
\n $c^{-1}R$ \n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n $q_0 = \\epsilon^{-1}R = (ab+c)^{*}$\n
\n
\n $b(ab + c)^{*}$\n
\n
\n $\\emptyset$ \n
\n
\n $(ab + c)^{*}$ \n
\n
\n
\n
\n $q_1 = b(ab + c)^{*}$\n
\n
\n $\\emptyset$ \n
\n
\n $(ab + c)^{*}$\n
\n
\n $\\emptyset$ \n
\n
\n
\n
\n $q_2 = \\emptyset$\n
\n
\n $\\emptyset$ \n
\n
\n $\\emptyset$ \n
\n
\n $\\emptyset$ \n
\n
